goal:
Crack the password of the Wifi!

NOTE : Before running the lab you must open a terminal and launch the cmd
"modprobe mac80211_hwsim"

This is a simulator of 802.11 radio(s), so you will not need a functioning network card to practice Wifi Hacking!

Prerequisites : Install aircrack-ng on your machine

 

 P.S. if you are curious to know how it works, check out my github repo  https://github.com/ale753/shinai-fi
solution:
if you started the lab, the AP and the stations are already sending packets each other.Open a terminal and type :

airmon-ng start wlan0


This will allow you to setup your interface wlan0 in monitor mode.

Note that monitor mode is enabled for [phy0]wlan0 on [phy0]wlan0mon and we will use wlan0mon.

airodump-ng wlan0mon -w packets.cap

Through this command we will begin sniffing the packets in the area and saving it in a file of extension .cap. If you do not specify a folder this file will be saved in your home directory.


Airodump-ng will show you real time informations about the visible Access point in the area and the stations connected to it. In this case we have one access point (the modem) and two stations that will connect to it.

What we need to know about all these informations?

BSSID : it's the mac address of all the visible routers in the area

ESSID : the name of our target modem to hack

ENC-CIPHER-AUTH : these three fields specify the type of encryption of the packets and the authentication protocol.

Since in our case it is WPA2-CCMP-PSK we need to wait for an handshake to come. When a station, that it could be a mobile station or not, begins the authentication process with the AP it will begin the 4-way-hadshake that we need to capture in order to start an offline bruteforce attack.

In this case we will perform a passive attack, waiting for the station to connect to the AP, that will happen at around 1 minute. In a real scenario if it takes too much time, you could send a deauthentication attack to a station that is connected to the target AP, forcing it to reconnect so you can capture the new handshake.

Once you see on the top right "WPA Handshake : 6A:D5:26:64:88:DA" it means that the station whose BSSID is 6A:D5:26:64:88:DA has attempted to connect to the AP. At this point you can stop collecting packets and stop airodump with CTRL-C.

 In this guide I will not go in the details on how aircrack-ng performes the attack. In a very simplified way, it tries to find the PSK key by a bruteforce attack, using a dictionary of passwords. However if the password is not contained in the dictionary it is nearly impossible to find it.

Find your .cap file in your directory (in my case the file name is packets.cap-01.cap). Download the rockyou dictionary from internet and launch :

aircrack-ng packets.cap-01.cap -w rockyou.txt

The password should be found at around 5% of the dictionary and it is...

 

 ... jhonnybravo
